reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: Kickstarter backer

tl;dr: Consider buying if you're a Wipeout fan, keep a close eye on it if you what you see looks interesting. Not remotely enough content for most buyers.

The following is based on the Early Access launch version of the game.

From some of the original Wipeout developers comes an extremely bare-bones but promising taste of a new AG racing game. At launch there is a single track, one craft, two modes, two weapons and three or so music tracks. Although this is in an early alpha state, the core mechanics are surprisingly satisfying. Compared to Wipeout, the handling is much heavier, collisions are much more punishing, and boosts are more rewarding. Accelerating into turns is not a viable strategy. To my delight, they managed to capture the awesome feeling of gliding as if on auto-pilot when completing three or four tricky turns from Wipeout.

Even as someone with experience in this type of game, placing first in the race took nearly an hour. Collision damage makes it very likely that you'll die in your first attempt. Learning the track and placement of boost pads seems essential to winning. Currently there is one weapon in the game, and it's tricky to learn to use (hold the fire button until the missile locks on, then release). Overall, there is an hour of satisfying content here, obviously not yet enough to justify a €28 price tag.

As for performance and ease of use, this game is very limited as you can imagine. The menus are not responsive, there's very little in terms of an options menu, but it does feature borderless windowed mode which came at a cost of around 10fps. On my hardware (GTX770, i5-4690k factory settings) I could maintain above 60fps in fullscreen mode on the highest preset. Sound effects don't appear to be implemented, though the music will be appealing if you enjoyed the soundtrack of the Wipeout games. The visuals are great, though obviously could use polish, and the track design seems solid for the first track.

Personally, I'm very much looking forward to seeing where this game goes and will update this review throughout development. I'm not a big fan of racing, but I always liked the Wipeout games for their arcadey gameplay and split second handling combined with high fidelity visuals. Having played almost every entry to the series, I was disappointed to hear that Studio Liverpool was shutting down, and I'm glad that Wipeout is getting a spiritual successor in the hands of what appear to be capable developers in the form of Formula Fusion.

Original review.

Formula Fusion is a futuristic racing game made by R8 Games partnering with Designers Republic. The game at launched in Kickstarter and Steam with the equivalent buzz of Yooka Laylee. Billed in many gaming journalism websites as a “spiritual successor made by former Studio Liverpool developers”, sleek looking graphics, the intent to ride on the E-Sports bandwagon and delivering high speed antigravity racing game akin to the “agile, complex and nimble” WipEout and not the “straight speed, no turning required” F-Zero.

They say in Kickstarter that the initial £35,000 KS target was to allow them to create the “‘base game’, which will feature eight tracks created by the WipEout 3 track team and an early-access version featuring one fully developed track”. They actually doubled the goal to £79,656 and in 3 Aug, 2015, they launched this game to Steam.

Like any alpha, there are lots of bugs that has yet to be solved and content that is lacking at launch. You can wall ride your craft without care about the hull integrity without getting penalised by slowing the craft down. The UI is minimalistic; the bad kind of minimalism which you need to squint down the screen (not up!) to see the important information like the amount of weapons tokens to deploy your weapon, the time of your lap as well as the energy level that you’re in.

The replay value are also lacking. There are currently three tracks to choose from, all of which are reverse or reskins of one another. The 3 additional “QA tracks” exclusive to “Test Pilots” were textured in bare bones grey. One of the tracks struck me as amateurish and so basic that I personally doubt it's been made from some AAA developers like Studio Liverpool. The craft design were nice but currently all the teams selection are cosmetic and doesn’t affect the stats of the craft.

The weapons selection? Two. Just two different selections of weapons. One is a hold-space-for-three-seconds-to-fire rocket and the other is the fire and forget “force wall” in WipEout 3.

This would have been ok if the game is updated in a consistent time with a solid roadmap. Maybe monthly? Bi-monthly perhaps?

Nope! The last update of this game was in 25th August 2015. Even when they secured new investment on the 5th of November, there’s no update from the time this review was posted. There are no guaranteed dates for the next update.

All of this while some of the development staff and 2 community managers (one of which I will vouch on being extremely supportive) were laid off as their contract ended.

Formula Fusion itself is nice, shiny and cool to show off your friends your GTX 980’s capabilities but from the content, the update schedule and stability as a company, it’s plainly not worth your $20.

It really felt like you were in a near future, deadly racing competition with high stakes. All the cool looking ships, the high tech dangerous weapons, and the smooth, fast steering of the ships. The OST added hugely to the experience, and add it althogether, you had an incredible, atmospheric, futuristic, intense racing game.

I don't know what the road map is for this game, but as it stands, it has none of that. There are long stretches of road where you have no music. Just the quiet noise of the engine. When you grind against the wall, it doesn't feel like there's any impact, you just slow down a bit. Additionally, it sounds like dragging a cinder block across concrete. Not very inspiring. While the steer stays within the ballpark of the previous WipEout games, it doesn't feel as good. I haven't been able to pour as many hours into this yet as I have the Wipeout games, but here's my thoughts.

As far as AG racers are concerned, this game has serious potential to outclass them all, but I won't discuss features we don't have yet, only what we do.

Currently what we have is several tracks, some AI races and time trials with two speed classes. It may not seem like much but the devs do a good job keeping me playing with competitions for fastest lap. There seems to be a bit of disagreement on the handling, but honestly I have that same feeling coming into a new racer each time, and after a couple of hours around a bunch of tracks I think I've learned how to handle the new craft.

Same goes for this one. At first I felt like the f4000 was too much like a floating tank, but now (and after some apparent tweaks) I realize just how nimble the craft can be. The f3000 however, was like a warm knife through butter, and the sensation of speed was unreal.

The camera itself is what took getting used to most. Rather than directly follow the craft, it angles based on ship position on the track. Initially this is quite disorienting and unwieldy but again, you learn the benefits soon enough and can really use it to your advantage. There's also a full-detail pilot view which just looks rad (and I look forward to trying that with VR support.)

In terms of track design each one gets better and better, with a very strong start. You don't always need airbrakes, but at times they are a godsend. I like this direction myself, as it means on the right line you can blitz a corner at near full speed and never come off the accelerator. And when you've hit a few boost pads beforehand, this can be a really awesome experience.

In terms of collision, I still think this could use a bit of work. One of my fondest memories of AG games is how in Wipeout 64 you could graze walls if you were pointed just right and not lose all of your speed. Sure, it doesn't punish you as hard for missing your line, but it made it feel so much more intense to scrape by on the outside line to steal a position. But I do understand why they've got it as it is. It's also refreshing that even on slimmer tracks it still feels impossible to pinball.

Overall, what we have now is awesome, and I'm glad I got in when I did. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys these types of games, and even those who haven't tried them for sure.

I'll update this review when there's more to report on.

From the ashes of the Wipeout series comes Formula Fusion.

Currently, this game is in an early alpha stage, meaning that there isn't a lot of content. However, what is currently present is certainly promising.

At the time of writing, there is only one or two tracks, one craft, two songs to the soundtrack, and two weapons. The quantity of such features are sure to rise once the game reaches higher stages in development. You are able to select colours for your craft, which is a nifty feature and it would be nice to see it expanded upon in the future.

The user interface does require a bit of work. At first I found myself clicking on a UI element which didn't display anything due to the fact that I didn't click on the previous one, and it wasn't obvious at first glance. However once I had it figured out, it did the job well enough.

The gameplay was pretty good! The turning took a little getting used to but once mastered, it became an easy task to pull off. The speed pad boosts are much more rewarding than you'd find in the Wipeout games. The in-game HUD could have been a bit better. Most of the information regarding the ship (such as armour, speed, etc.) is shown right behind the ship, which is constantly moving and turning. At times I was unable to tell how much armour my ship had left, and when I attempted to check I was often thrown off course. Though that may just me me, other people may tell you otherwise.

As it stands, this game is on a good path and has tons and tons of potential, and I can't wait to see what becomes of it in the future.

Good luck, R8 games!

I was curious about this game after I played FAST Racing NEO for Wii U, for which I was a bit disappointed from the big amount of glitches present in the game, so I decided to buy it to try something similiar, but different at the same time.

Let's start from the game's positive aspects.

- Tracks desing is great, each one of them has got an unique setting and a different kind of driving design that makes them easily recognizeable from each other.
Mannahatta is absolutely astonishing, with it's rain effect and under costruction/hi-tech scenario in which tha track is installed.
Atlas Torres concept is almost never treated in actual racing video games, so I suggest you to check some pics of the track to make you understand what I mean.
Niagara GP track design is good, but it's a little bit naked of elements surrounding the track. An update is planned the next month for Niagara GP, and I hope for a good revamp of the track.

- Ships are separated in classes, which is a good thing for racing and time trial competitions. This choice prevents a single ship to prevail on the other ones, and gives the opportunity to try different competition settings. F4000 is the main ship they're working on actually, and it feels really good to drive. The ship sliding feels natural and fun to play. F3000 is a lot faster than F4000, but it has similiar physics to the last I mentioned, so it feels a little uncomfortable to drive for who has never tried it. Just make some practice, and you'll find out it doesn't feel that bad to drive.

- Game's graphics looks amazing for this alpha stage; details for the two available ships and for the tracks themselves are truly curate. Graphic effects are still a bit strange, but for this alpha stage they're pretty good. I couldn't imagine how the game would look in it's complete release.

- The actual OST of the game is good to enjoy, I would like to hear something more like this in the future releases. More Drum 'n' Bass, please!

- Practice Mode is good for those that don't understand well the physics of the game, making you avoid to touch walls with antigravitational waves that pull you at the center of the track. Give it a try if you just bought the game and you want to get into the game a little.

Let's now talk about the game negative aspects.

- As of now, there are only two items available, and you could set just one of them available for a race. They still feel weird to use, as they don't slow you down when you get hit by them; you just lose shield. I hope they will add more of them in a Mario Kart way, and that they will be revisited with the full release.

- A single boost pad sometimes could give you a double boost out of nothing. A glitch that needs to be fixed soon.

- Passing between two near boost pads with the ship could cause you to get a doubled boost. This compromises/randomizes a little time trial competitions, and could be extremely clutch on races when you don't except to get a double boost.

- Opponent's AI is still a bit easy to beat. Also, the frame rate drops and then fluctuates between 25-45 fps on tracks like Niagara GP and Atlas Torres when AI is moving. An issue that needs to be fixed soon.

I also want to talk about neutral aspects of the game.

- The ship's handling feel ok by now, but it's still a bit woody, especially when you're trying to countersteer. But R8 Games is actually working on it, releasing with every patch a refreshed and refined handling system.

Even if there are a lot of things to fix for this game, it's still in early access, and to see an huge work like that drives me to think at what the game could look once it's finished, and to tell you to buy the game if you like racing games.

Also, there are a lot of features that are coming to the game in the future, like online multiplayer races, endurances, more items and a lot of stuff like that, so the game will have a lot to offer.

If you like Antigravity racing games or the Wipeout series, give Formula Fusion a chance, you won't be disappointed once the game will be released.
(This game review will be edited until the full release of the game, to match up with early access releases details.)

Early Access Review

(In fondo per l'italiano)

From what you can see, Formula Fusion is a futuristic racing game with weapons, heavily inspired to Wipeout. The gameplay is solid and smooth but at the moment the game has very little content:  New York Map (Normal, Reversed, Night) and asingle ship with 5 colors, to test out track and AI.

The game looks overall good, as an Early Access, but it lacks of speed. Not sure if the vehicles are slow or it totally lacks the sensation of speed, but is still extremely far from the greatness of F-Zero (or Wipeout high difficulties).

However the game is still in Early Access (much more like a tech demo), it will probably have more modes once completed, maybe with a proper anti-gravity speed.

It's a good bet for any Wipeout fan, the others can wait though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sony is dumb as hell for letting go of the WipEout franchise. WipEout is the pinnacle of high speed anti-gravity racing, surpassing F-Zero and any other contender with ease.

With that being said, what Formula Fusion promises to bring to the table is a successor to this franchise that can exist outside of the PlayStation brand.

The graphics look great, however the ship design is lacking compared to the original WipEout series and the handling model is most similar to WipEout Fusion for PlayStation2 which is generally considered as the the least impressive game in the entire franchise. The soundtrack is not up to par with franchise standards either, though this was predictable since the developer no longer has access to the massive library of Sony-owned music.

I want to recommend this game, but I feel as though the future of this game is uncertain. R8Games steam profile has 48 hours on CS:GO, 25 hours on CS:Source, and 0.4 hours on Formula Fusion. Thats not very encouraging.

I plan on keeping this review updated, but right now I would only suggest purchasing this game if you are familiar with the WipEout franchise and want to see this title succeed. For those who haven't had the pleasure of playing one of the previous games, I would say; enter at your own risk. The game is very small at the moment with what is essentially only one track and one vehicle.

This game has insane potentional, but it has very VERY big shoes to fill.

It's sad to see this game go this direction. This is merely a prototype with pretty graphics.
The ship handling has nothing to do with physics, it's only an animation that doesn't feel authentic at all.
The fact that this is in early acces makes me sad. As a TTP backer, I feel somewhat betrayed.
Just don't buy it yet if you're looking for something fun to play.

Update:

Some time passed and they changed the handling a bit. Now it is even harder to control. They claim that the handling is closer to the older Wipeout games which might be harder to control for most people. Now, Formula Fusion is hard to control but for the wrong reasons. The ships are not responsive at all and they still seem to stick to the ground. It feels like there is a delay before it actually starts steering.
It is confusing how little progress this game makes.

BallisticNG nailed the handling (which is being developed by one guy, mind that). It is hard to control but it's not the game's fault. In this game I feel like racing in something like a rally car which is hard to control but still possible to master. If you're looking for some true Wipeout action, go check out BallisticNG. It's free and open source.

Edit:
The handling has been revised, feels much more solid! Give it a go, I guess.

I feel sad about making this review, because I was really looking forward to this game, I've been a wipEout fan since I got a PSP and played a lot of HD Fury.

Formula Fusion was a promising spiritual successor to the wipEout franchise after being shut down in 2012, and had a early crowdfunding (TPP) and a Kickstarter (I was part of the TPP). The problem is it feels like it's going nowhere, and that the game was mean't to be released in 2016, and I can't even tell if this would be considered ready for a 2017 launch, every (the few) updates they had, the physics were completely different every time, it looks like they can't consider sticking to 1 set of physics without changing it again on the next update. The current version lack massively of content, and is extremely buggy, unpolished and doesn't feel stable at all. The only + I can give to this game are the graphics of the only tracks there is.

To those you don't even know what wipEout is, do not buy this. To those who knows, buy at your own risk.
